—It was back in 1990 when he dealt with Western Australia specifically. But, worse than that, in the run-up to the last election, following many years of continual complaint, I had included as part of the opposition's approach to the election a clear statement that this program was so dishonest, so blatantly crooked, so disgraceful that it would not feature in a coalition government, that we would cancel this program, we would end it, we would finish it off because it was not a sports program, it was a vote-buying shonk. It was the illegitimate creature of former Senator Richardson, I suppose one could say, brought into the world in a more developed state by Mrs Kelly, but that might involve some curious analogies. But we could say this: if Mrs Kelly was the monkey then former Senator Richardson was certainly the organ-grinder—a phrase which could have some curious connotations at the moment.

PARA.TAB: I am particularly angry about the fact that my proposal, as shadow minister for sport, to get rid of this dishonest program—subsequently proved to be dishonest—was attacked violently by the people opposite who, as a result of this deception among many other deceptions, bought their way back into office.
Having moved that the Senate take note of this document, I note one particular part of it especially and that is the quote in the government response, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The government will not be extending the present program beyond 30 June 1995, nor will it be introducing a new program in the foreseeable future.

It goes on to explain why. It says that in the immediate future the government will be concentrating on the human aspects of sport, on achievement and attainment of personal goals by athletes rather than bricks and mortar.

PARA.TAB: I am wondering who wrote this stuff. Did he or she just take it out of my pre-election sports statement? This is exactly what I wanted to do. I wanted to make certain that government money went to sportspeople, not to political stunts like this one. Is it not amazing? After the election, after it had done its work, this shonky scheme has been dropped by this government because even it could not stand the smell of the sports rorts still hanging around its neck. In fact, as former Senator Walsh pointed out, many of these vote purchasing schemes have more negatives than positives.

The unfortunate thing is, of course, that the positives for this government took place before the election and the negatives after it. What a shame that that happened because on this side of the chamber, we—and certainly me in particular—were all complaining about this project, pointing out its dishonesty, long before the election. But, I am afraid, the press gallery could not have cared less—we could not get a line. It was fortunate that the Auditor-General, who attended and continues to attend Senate estimates meetings, thank heavens, became aware of this issue, the dishonest nature of these grants and the deceptions by the ministers involved when they were pretending that guidelines were being met when they were not. It was only because the Auditor-General picked up this ball, as his responsibility, and ran with it that it became an issue that attracted the press gallery and therefore the people of Australia.

The consequences were that the minister who had misled the parliament on this matter `resigned'. I can remember the document that Mrs Kelly put out before the last election attacking me, my policy and the statements that I had put out—the very sound and sensible document showing how sport would benefit under a coalition government—saying it was a disgrace that we were taking money away from sport. It is funny, I have not heard Mrs Kelly say anything about the fact that the government will not be extending the present program, that it is killing it off.

I wonder why, before the last election, Mrs Kelly found any suggestion that we would cut it off to be so disgraceful, but when her own government ends it, there is nothing wrong. The silent Mrs Kelly, who was so voluble before the election, but who has been utterly silent after it now that this shonky project that she maladministered has been cut off: we do not hear any complaint from her.

One gets accustomed to the sorts of deception and dishonesty that took place on behalf of this government in the run up to the last election. We all know that the anti-GST campaign was probably the most dishonest that any of us have struck. But I think that many sports people have forgotten the level of dishonesty in a government which protested about ending a program when we proposed it before the election, and then did what we proposed after the election. I am surprised that the government did not find some greater excuse for doing so, but it probably assumed that it could lie its way out of this one, as it has lied its way out of other issues. It did not even show a flicker of embarrassment, but I suppose it should not because it has become so expert at misleading the Australian people.

Let us remember exactly what this report of the Auditor-General, to which the government has responded, is all about. Before doing that, I point out that this shonky and dishonest program that the government has run on and off since 1988 was to have been evaluated, according to the government's response, before the government would consider its possible continuation. The response says:

SPEECH.PARA: Given that the Program is not to be extended or a similar program introduced in the foreseeable future, and the Program has been thoroughly scrutinised by the Auditor-General, it is not now intended to undertake a further evaluation of the Program.

I will bet it is not. The last thing this government would want would be any kind of thorough evaluation of this program. We know it is a shonky program. The Auditor-General has certainly established that in the making of the grants there was behaviour which was a disgrace in the sense there was a lack of documentation and an openness to fraud, but we do not know about the implementation of the program. The Auditor-General has not reported on the implementation of the program because the program has not finished being implemented. In fact, it is being rolled over again until the end of the next financial year.

PARA.TAB: That leads me to the next disgraceful and dishonest element of this shonky dishonest deal. Every year the government would put out in its budget a statement, `This is the wonderful, huge total we are going to spend on sport this year.' It would include multi-millions under this program. Come the end of the year, that money would not have been spent. So it would go onto the next budget. And, having falsely claimed it was going to spend $80-odd million, it would spend $6 million less—it would spend, say, $74 million, and these are not precise figures but just an indication. The following year the government would get up and say, `Whacko. This year we are going to increase our spending to $80 million.' It would include again in its dishonest polemic the same money being rolled over and over and over; the same money claimed to have been spent on sport but not being spent that year at all being pushed forward to other years.

We see the same thing this year. I think something like $6 1/2 million which was supposed to have been spent in the 1993-94 financial year will now be spent in 1994-95. In this budget the government is claiming it is going to spend $13 1/2 million under this project, except that it is double claiming $6 1/2 million that should have been spent in the current year to June. It is dishonesty upon dishonesty, shonk upon shonk.

I am glad that the Auditor-General's report has effectively forced the government into cancelling this disgraceful program that all ministers of this government embraced for years as something they saw no problem with or objected to—at least, not outside—and which they used as a weapon to beat us over the head with when we were honest before the last election. All ministers in this government stand condemned for their silence on this disgraceful matter. It was brought to their attention often enough in this chamber, going back to 1990. They knew it perfectly well.

I often wonder whether ex-Senator Richardson's earlier than anticipated retirement from this chamber had anything to do with the fact that we gave him fair notice that we were going to pursue every one of the disgraceful grants that took place when he was the minister. Although, I must say that he was a little more clever about it than Mrs Kelly. In his case he did not ask the department to categorise them and to put them in some order of priority. He did nothing like that.

I remember his response in a Senate estimates committee when I asked him what happened about notifying these things, and what role did the department play. His response was simple, direct and politically astute. He said, `If a grant is awarded I write the letter to them. If a grant request is knocked back then the department writes them, and that is the role of the department.' That means that ex-Senator Richardson would not be capable of falling into the ridiculous situation that Mrs Kelly fell into where she denied in the parliament that various grants had not filled the requirements of the grant conditions. She denied, for example, that there had been late grants. Obviously, if ministers are running everything themselves and do not have the department participating, they can get away with what they like and no-one would know.

Mrs Kelly, having involved the department, then left herself open to attack when she misled the parliament about the propriety or not and the status of various applications. Nonetheless, it was clear to ex-Senator Richardson that he was going to face months of non-stop flack over quite proper criticism of his sports rorts deal. The whole concept of federal involvement in facilities began under Mr John Brown, the minister for having a good time, and pigs. Mr John Brown decided that it would be a good idea, and many people supported this concept, if large national projects were funded by the national government—projects which would increase the capacity in Australia for international performance; for example, a swimming pool in Hobart which I know is close to Senator Calvert's heart but has not been funded.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am going to follow on about that.

—Or something that was closer to Mr Brown's heart, the Parramatta football stadium which he suddenly discovered was a matter of national importance. No doubt the Parramatta Football Club recognises that it is a matter of national significance that it is coming bottom of the Sydney league ladder at the moment. Here we have a situation where the initial program had some kind of basis of dishonesty. Even if Mr Brown used it as a local political rort, nonetheless, that facility is very useful. But let us remember how this whole concept degenerated under this vote buying crooked scheme introduced by this government.

PARA.TAB: This is a crooked scheme which the current minister—and I have to commend him for it—has recognised should not proceed. I acknowledge his recognition of the good sense in the coalition's policy before the last election in that the government:

SPEECH.PARA: will be concentrating on the human aspects of sport—on achievement and attainment of personal goals by athletes—rather than bricks and mortar. Let us go back to what the Auditor-General said to which this is a response. He stated:
ANAO noted some anomalies in the approval of grants—
worth just under $30 million—

by the Minister but was unable to resolve them because the reasons for decisions were not adequately documented. For the same reason claims that decisions on the allocation of grants were politically motivated could not be put to rest.
The Auditor-General could not put to rest the assertions that I had made that this was a politically motivated, crooked deal. He continues:

ANAO considers that it is in the interest of a Minister to document the reasons for individual decisions to allay such allegations and to provide accountability for decisions . . . ANAO found that the Department's administration of the program was weak:
.insufficient information was sent to the Minister to allow the Minister to make informed decisions
.the objectives of the program were unclear
.the procedures for processing applications were poor. Details on applications were not checked and necessary documentation was not followed up where it was missing
.documentation supporting the categorisation process was inadequate
.there is a need for greater consultation with other interested bodies, e.g. State and local governments
.projects were not monitored systematically to ensure completion or achievement of program objectives
.certain administrative procedures left the program open to fraud and the program fraud control plan was out of date, and
.there is poor performance information.
As a result ANAO is not able to report that the program is an efficient and effective use of public money.
Hear, hear! We told this government that, and we have been telling it that for years.

PARA.TAB: Let us get a feeling of the size of it. This program had its origins in the community cultural, recreational and sporting facilities program approved in the 1988-89 budget when the government agreed to provide $13 million over three years. In the 1991-92 budget the government extended it for a further three years at a cost of $30 million. Then in November 1992, when it found that it could not spend its money under the shonky One Nation statement, it reallocated this money, and it reallocated just under $19 million into this program. That is something like $62 million that has been spent on this vote buying program since 1988-89. In fact, in something like three years $62 million was allocated to this vote buying shonk of a program. The Auditor-General states:

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of the original program was to assist State and local government authorities to make up the backlog in the provision of basic sporting and recreational facilities.

Yet we find in this report the Auditor-General complaining that there had not been adequate cooperation, discussion and agreement with local government bodies. It is just incredible. I will not go over the detail because it has been gone over often enough. We know that a bigger proportion of those grant applications which did not meet the criteria were granted approval than were those that met the top grade of criteria and, of course, the key criteria to this government was what electorate the application was in.

PARA.TAB: Fortunately, a great number of the recommendations put up by the Auditor-General have been accepted by the government, but it seems to have knocked back the proposal that the number of applications received should be limited and restricted to larger projects. In other words, going back to the John Brown concept and saying that it is a matter for government decision. As the government has decided not to proceed with this program anyway, I suppose we can say that it does not really matter.
What does matter is that the Auditor-General notes:

SPEECH.PARA: The findings of a number of official inquiries in recent years, in particular, the Fitzgerald inquiry in Queensland, the WA Inc Royal Commission in Western Australia and the State Bank inquiry in South Australia point to the risks to the public interest of a system of government where there is no effective accountability of those trusted with public power.

They are terribly important words. They underline the need for there to be a powerful and effective Auditor-General, because it is the Auditor-General who, in this case, has pointed publicly and effectively to the fact that there was no effective accountability of those trusted with public power, and those people misused their status, their power and the public purse to buy votes in this situation. The Auditor-General goes on:

One of the key principles underlying Australian constitutional arrangements is that the institutions and agencies of government and officials (elected and non-elected) exist to serve the interests of the public. If public confidence in Government is to be maintained public officials—who act in trust on behalf of all citizens—must ensure that their actions and decisions, however unintentionally, do nothing to allow any suspicion that official power and position is being used for self-interested or partisan purposes.

Public power and public resources are delegated to governments which are expected to act in the national interest. The use of public resources contributed by force of law, not voluntarily, by taxpayers requires particular care in ensuring that defensible conduct can be demonstrated.
In passing he also notes:
Without proper records the program will always be susceptible to allegations of impropriety.

That important matter that there must be effective accountability underlines the fact that this chamber must not allow the Keating government to emasculate the Auditor-General, to deprive him of the resources that would enable him to keep pointing out disgraceful conduct like this lack of proper accountability and to leave a situation where he says he cannot disprove the proposition that this was a political stunt, and a disgraceful one at that. I commend the Auditor-General once again. I am glad the government has responded by accepting at least the bulk of the Auditor-General's recommendations. I think it ought to accept them all.

PARA.TAB: I finish by saying what a shame it is that the government government's decision—or admission as it is now really—is that this program is to end. What a shame that decision was not announced before the last election. What a shame the government did not have the integrity to front up to the Australian people and say that it would not be continued. What a shame the government did not have the guts to say that in the foreseeable future there would be no such program. What a shonky lot. What a disgraceful group of people who denied the Australian people the right to make a proper judgment on them by delaying until now the statement that this program, which is dishonest to the poor and which they defended to the hilt, was not going to proceed once they had conned the Australian people into voting for them.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government's response to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts review of a report of an efficiency audit by the Auditor-General of the community cultural, recreational and sporting facilities program has now been tabled. I think it is fair to say that the standing committee, in its recommendations and deliberations, decided that it believed there was little need to add to the Auditor-General's recommendations. It did, of course, come forward with five measures `to ensure that in the future the program can be adequately monitored by the Parliament.'

PARA.TAB: If the government were to introduce a new program of assistance for sporting facilities, these measures would be taken into account along with the Auditor-General's best practice guide for the administration of grants. However, as Senator Baume pointed out in his contribution, I have announced that the facilities program will not be extended; the program is finished.

The government will be refocusing its initiatives, as we heard the senator say, on the human aspects of sport and taking the emphasis away from bricks and mortar. That was reinforced with the $135 million to be provided over the next six years to prepare Australian athletes for both the Atlanta and Sydney olympic games. That is real evidence of the government's commitment to those who are participating in sport.

Notwithstanding this change in emphasis, the current program will continue during 1994-95 when the remaining projects that have been funded will be finalised. Claims against existing grants must be lodged with my department by 20 May 1995. I can say that all grant recipients have been advised of this by the department. They all know of this requirement that there will be no payments processed after that date. I will ensure that that message is reinforced from time to time by correspondence from my department.

I can assure the Senate that the scheme will be very properly administered over this period of time. The Auditor-General's recommendations, which impact on the current program, have already been implemented. It is probably important, given the rather unkind comments—

TALK.START.PARA: —Only because you got caught with your hand in the till.
—I was not the minister, and the senator knows it.
—It doesn't make it any more savoury because you weren't the minister, does it? It did happen.

—I thank the senator for that. I think it is reasonable to place these two reports in context. The government provided some $60 million for the development of community facilities through the sports portfolio in the period since 1988-89. In that time, over 1,400 projects have been assisted and they are projects that otherwise would not have gone ahead. Of the 1,064 projects approved in rounds three and four of the program, I have been advised by my department that more than 60 per cent have already received their final payment.

PARA.TAB: The Senate ought to be aware that these projects represent facilities that have been built right around this country in local communities and they are facilities that are providing opportunities for ordinary Australians to participate in recreational activities of their own choosing.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are not trying to justify the white board, are you?
—No-one has questioned the worth of the program.
—Come on.

—There has obviously been criticism of the administration of the program but no-one has criticised the worth of the program. Given the typically intemperate and unreasonable comments of Senator Baume, even though I did not drag a crystal ball into the chamber, I predict there will be some more intemperate and unreasonable comments made by other senators from the coalition side who might contribute to this debate. But there has never been a finding of impropriety or fraudulent activity in relation to this scheme.

PARA.TAB: I can say that all reasonable steps have been taken by the government, and by me as the new minister responsible for sport, to improve the administration of this program. I have ensured that the program as it now stands is efficiently and effectively administered. There is no doubt that the recommendations of the Auditor-General have been promptly and fully implemented by the government. I believe that no fair-minded senator can argue to the contrary.

I look forward as the minister to what I think is going to be a tremendous opportunity for Australian sport as we give new focus to those people who will be using these and other sporting facilities in the lead-up to the Olympic Games in the year 2000, as the government puts its money where its mouth is in relation to our athlete preparation program for the Olympic Games and gives the appropriate emphasis that is due to those participating in sport and recreational activities in this country, not only the elite athletes but also young Australians who are involved in sport and recreation activities, disabled athletes and all those who stand to benefit from the tremendous commitment that the government has made to sport, not only in this budget with our $135 million contribution over six years for the athlete preparation program, but also ever since this government has been in office.

The miserable performance of the opposition when it was in government is highlighted by the fact of the enormous contribution currently made in the federal budget, well in excess of $150 million, including $50 million over the next three years for facilities in Sydney for the Olympic Games. That amount of money, well in excess of $150 million, compares with the contribution of these mean-minded individuals on the other side of the chamber. Their last effort in the last year of a coalition government was—wait for it—$14.5 million.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is it worth in dollars today?

PARA.TAB: Let me say to Senator Campbell that that was his party's last effort. Senator Campbell has all my commiserations as he struggles, as the new shadow minister for sport, to justify the performance of his party when it was in government. That surely shows, even to Senator Campbell, the contempt his party showed for Australian sport. However, I wish him well in the task of turning that attitude around. Senator Campbell may even do something that Senator Baume and predecessors attempted to achieve over the past decade or so, and that is to produce an opposition policy on sport and recreation. That is very doubtful, but I look forward in the forthcoming months to Senator Campbell's justification for his own miserable, mean-minded and inadequate record.

TALK.START.PARA: —Be fair. I wasn't around then.

—I am being very fair. Indeed, I am giving an extremely fair analysis of the performance of Senator Campbell's party on the subject of sport. That policy was hopeless and inadequate. Indeed, it was so disorganised that at no time could his party get pen to paper and draw up a sports policy. Compared to many of his colleagues, Senator Campbell's task will be pretty easy. At least by comparison with his colleagues, Senator Campbell probably will be a shining light. Compared to the performance of the present government, that of the opposition stinks.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner) for his welcome to me as shadow minister for sport. It was very generous and fair-minded of him. It epitomises the Aussie spirit of a fair go on the playing field.

PARA.TAB: I intend today to focus on an amendment to Senator Baume's motion to take note of the document, which is the government's response to the Auditor-General's report No. 9. I foreshadow moving the following amendment:

SPEECH.PARA: At the end of the motion, add "and the Senate also:

(a)condemns the government for its entirely unsatisfactory response to the Auditor-General's reports on Sports Rorts on which $60 million was spent in a blatant program of political pork barrelling which failed to increase participation in sport, recreation or cultural activities; and

(b)further condemns the government for inflicting retribution on the Australian National Audit Office by slashing its funding by $7.5 million contrary to commitments made by the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Evans, on 3 March 1994 in the so called "accountability package".

We cannot allow this opportunity on which the government has tabled a response to the Auditor-General's report without supporting such an amendment in order to highlight the unacceptable nature of the response and also to recognise what has taken place in the aftermath of the sports rorts inquiry.

PARA.TAB: Many people would have us believe that just because of the resignation of one insignificant minister as a player flitting across the stage of politics, in the words of John Stone, all of a sudden everything will be okay. Senator Evans rose in this place as Leader of the Government on 3 March and proposed a package of measures called the accountability package. I will go through that package shortly. However, we need to discover whether the accountability package has even been put into place and whether it is good enough to sweep the sports rorts affair under the carpet. I put it to the Senate that it is not good enough.

Senator Baume has put to the chamber articulately the unsatisfactory nature of the response. In its response the government said that the program had been thoroughly scrutinised by the Auditor-General and that it was not intended to undertake any further evaluation of the program.

The minister in his remarks a few moments ago made some outrageous claims about how good the program was. He said that nobody has condemned the usefulness of the program. Indeed, he went on to say that the facilities built with all this money would make a great contribution to our Olympic campaign. That is the greatest amount of hogwash that I have heard coming from this minister's mouth in the last half hour. It is blatantly wrong.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not in the last half hour surely.

—Well, we have a lot of hogwash from the minister every half-hour and that is the biggest amount this half-hour. I challenge the minister to go through all the facilities that have been contributed to by this program over the past four years and to come back to the Senate in a couple of weeks time, or towards the end of the current sitting before 1 July, or whenever we get out of this place, and inform the Senate which of these facilities will be of assistance to our Olympic campaign. If he does that honestly, he will find that virtually none of the facilities that have been built with this pork-barrelling money will have very much to do with our Olympic effort.

PARA.TAB: On that same issue the people in the upper echelons of sport in Australia recognise a need for more facilities in this country. John Brown, the minister at the time, who invented or developed the program, recognised, as Senator Baume acknowledged, the need for more money to be spent on sporting facilities. We have some excellent sporting facilities in this country but very few are in regional areas and away from the major capital cities. We need some major facilities to ensure that potential athletes and elite athletes in particular do not have to travel literally thousands of miles to be able to undertake the fundamental training that is required if they are to reach the top of their sport both in Australia and internationally. I think it is fair to say that when Mr Brown envisaged this program, those sorts of facilities would have helped Australia. What we now have is a blatant political pork barrel, widely recognised as one of the most blatant political pork barrels seen in Australian politics.

It might be worth mentioning what a pork barrel is. The word has been thrown around politics quite a lot, particularly in the wake of the sports rorts affair. I have always wondered where the word came from and I am sure that many people share my curiosity. I asked the staff of the library to pull out a definition of pork barrel and this afternoon they kindly provided me with extracts from pages 596 and 597 of Safire's New Political Dictionary, which has some good quotes about pork barrel. The term goes back to the 1800s and it seems that a Mr E.E. Hale in a story called The Children of the Public in 1863, a story that appeared in Frank Leslie's Illustrated Newspaper—

TALK.START.PARA: —I know it well.
—Something that we have probably read many times, Senator Calvert, and have in all our libraries. He helped to popularise the term. In chapter one, entitled `The Pork Barrel', Hale wrote:

SPEECH.PARA: We find that, when an extraordinary contingency arises in life, as just now in ours, we have only to go to our pork barrel, and the fish rises to our hook or spear.
The term was widely used by the early 1900s. By the 1870s, congressmen were regularly referring to `pork' and the word became part of the US political lexicon.
Time Magazine noted in 1948 that one Peter J. McGuinness:
. . . fished in Tammany's pork barrel for 28 years to bring improvements to `me people.'
In a Baltimore speech on inflation in 1952, Adlai Stevenson pledged:
. . . no pork-barrelling while our economy is in its present condition.

It is a shame that one Paul Keating did not pledge to have `no pork-barrelling' while we were in the middle of a recession. The whole of Australia was in a recession during the sports rorts grants but that did not stop Paul Keating from spending $60 million of taxpayers' money—borrowed money; actually bankcard money—on this pork-barrelling scheme.

PARA.TAB: We are informed by a Mr C.C. Maxey that the phrase `pork barrel' refers to the practice of periodically distributing salt pork to slaves from large barrels. In the 1919 edition of the National Municipal Review—Senator Calvert has probably read this one, too—he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Oftentimes the eagerness of the slaves would result in a rush upon the pork barrel, in which each would strive to grab as much as possible for himself. Members of Congress in the stampede to get their local appropriation items into the omnibus river and harbor bills behaved so much like Negro slaves rushing to the pork barrel, that these bills were facetiously styled "pork barrel" bills, and the system which originated them as thus become known as the pork-barrel system.
The sports rorts program prior to the last election became the biggest pork barrel in Australian political history. We saw nearly $50 million handed out in just two years.

PARA.TAB: The minister made some comments about the importance of using these facilities for the Olympics. To put that $50 million into context, this government has appropriated in this year's budget $20 million to find and train olympic athletes. This year and next year the government is giving less money to increasing participation in olympic sports, identifying olympic athletes and training those olympic athletes than it gave in the last two years to its political pork barrel sports rorts program. So that is the government's commitment to the Olympics. More money went to the sports rorts affair last year than is going to our olympic athletes this year. Let us get into perspective the Labor Party's commitment to the Olympics. I turn now to the accountability package because in the long term this will be of vital interest to Australia. We were told on 3 March when the government was trying to stop Senator Harradine, the Democrats and the Greens from voting for a Senate select committee inquiry into the sports rorts affair that there would be a whole range of accountability measures. I have the speech in front of me and I have highlighted some of the legs of those measures that need to be reviewed constantly. I committed to the Senate then that I would keep these measures under review.

Senator Evans came in here to try to assure my colleagues on the crossbenches that we did not need a Senate select committee inquiry into the sports rorts affair because this government was finally, after 11 years of mismanagement and closed and unaccountable government, all of a sudden going to turn over a new leaf. I doubted its sincerity. I am certain that the Democrat senators, the Green senators and Senator Harradine will also keep under close scrutiny the Leader of the Government's commitments to the Senate on that day.

In the budget brought down only a fortnight ago we saw one of the first commitments of the Leader of the Government fall over in one hit. Senator Evans referred to a whole range of measures to upgrade the office of Auditor-General, to make it more independent and to ensure that its resources were secure. He said that the ANAO would be getting a comprehensive, single line budget; that the Audit Office would be mandated as the sole auditor of all government departments, statutory authorities and GBEs without exception; and that the Auditor-General would become an statutory officer of the parliament and a separate statutory authority. These are all things that will be in the new audit act that we are yet to see.

Throughout the entire speech he gave the illusion that he was going to ensure that the Auditor-General was well resourced. He undertook, on behalf of the government, that he would review the forward estimates and funding for the audit office for 1994-95—we have just had the budget for 1994-95—following the outcome of an inquiry into the conduct of officers and departments in the so-called Centenary House affair.

I raised in the Senate, I think on 11 May, in a question to Senator Evans, why, if he has given such a commitment to fund the Auditor-General, have its funds been slashed by $10 million in this budget? That is a massive slashing to an organisation that has only a relatively meagre budget already.

SPEECH.PARA: The minister replied that it is all okay; that it is all to do with some changes in accounting, a few redundancies and a few abnormal items.

PARA.TAB: I was not happy with that response. I was very pleased that my colleague, Senator Parer, who is in the chamber today, decided to pursue that matter in estimates last week. He asked the officers from the Australian National Audit Office what was the state of their funding for this year. Was Senator Evans right, in other words? Had I made a fundamental mistake about the financing of the Auditor-General's office this year? Was it all a bookkeeping mistake that I could not work out because I just did not understand? On 27 May, Senator Parer said:

SPEECH.PARA: This was raised, I think, by a colleague of mine in the Senate. I would like to confirm that the Department of Finance made an arbitrary reduction of $10 million on your funding because of this failure to agree. Is that correct or not?
Mr Cochrane, an officer from the Auditor-General's office, said:

There are a variety of figures and adjustments in the total $10 million amount. The core amount that affects the financial statement funding, and which is the area that we are most worried about, is about $7 1/2 million.

I was wrong, I made a mistake—I was $2 1/2 million out! But the reality is that two months after the Leader of the Government stood up to convince Senator Harradine, the Democrats and the Greens that we did not need an inquiry into the sports rorts affair pork barrel, that the government was going to become accountable all of a sudden, that it was going to look after the Auditor-General and ensure that he was independent and well funded, the government slashed his funding by $7 1/2 million. So much so that Mr Cochrane in the estimates committee said:
The consequence is that the statutory work is not done—
that is, the statutory requirements for the Auditor-General to audit the government cannot be done under this budget—
or . . . we do not do a proportion of performance auditing.

The audit report No. 9 into the sports rorts pork-barrel affair was a performance audit. The government does not want performance audits. It did not want a performance audit into the crooked Dasfleet leases to the Transport Workers Union. It did not want a performance audit into why the Australian Construction Service was given the Maralinga contract. It does not want any performance audits. It does not want accountability and that is why it has slashed the Auditor-General's funds. That is a disgrace. It is a matter that I hope Senator Harradine, the Democrats and the Green senators from Western Australia will look at very closely. On 3 March they agreed not to have a Senate select committee inquiry into the sports rorts affair—something that required investigation by the parliament.

PARA.TAB: The Auditor-General basically found a smoking gun with the smell of cordite thick in the air. He found a minister who had destroyed documents. The smoking gun had been thrown into the river. Corruption, the Auditor-General said, could not be proved but it could not be disproved. So the Senate was faced with what was a smoking gun but it decided not to pursue an investigation. I say to the Senate that it made a big mistake on that day and I say to Senator Harradine and the Democrat senators that they should look at the performance of the 3 March government's accountability package because already it has fallen over.

The next thing that we should look at in the accountability package is the so-called ministerial code of conduct. A little committee was to be set up to write a little code of conduct for ministers. These ministers are so bad they need to have in writing what they should and should not do. We should not need a ministerial code of conduct but with these guys we do. We need a little handbook to hand to people such as Ros Kelly and Senator Faulkner when they take office setting out what they should and should not do.

If written, the ministerial code of conduct would probably say, `If the Senate passes a motion to table some documents, you will comply with it.' On 5 May, the Senate, by an overwhelming majority, resolved that Senator McMullan should table some documents about another secret deal between two government agencies down in Melbourne, again involving the Australian Construction Service—another secret deal that this government wants held up. One would think that if there were a ministerial code of conduct, one thing it would say is that when the Senate, the parliament of Australia, passes a motion that a minister must produce documents, he will do so. And one would think further that if that minister failed to produce those documents, as Senator McMullan did—he was censured on 10 May—he would try to correct that breach of the Senate's order. But no, Senator McMullan chose on the day he was asked to do so to fly to South America and again remain in breach of the Senate—which he remains to this day. Of course, the Senate will have to decide what to do to try to have Senator McMullan remedy that breach.

This is the sort of code of conduct that this Labor government would put down: `Forget the parliament—it is only just a minor hindrance. Forget the Auditor-General—we have promised that we will upgrade his resources but we will slash him by $7 1/2 million because the Senate will forget about it. Knowing that the inquiry had not got off the ground, knowing that it was due to report in May but that it had not even met, I asked Senator Cook back on 23 March 1994 what had happened to the inquiry. This inquiry had been foreshadowed back in October and we had still heard nothing of it by March. But he assured us, on 23 March, that it would report on 18 May. Even though I had raised concerns about the powers that the South Australian Auditor-General and Mr Boymal from the finance department had, Senator Cook said, `No, it's all okay. They have got all their powers. The inquiry can go ahead and it will be reporting on 18 May.'

We need to remember that the resources of the Auditor-General are reliant upon the outcome of the Centenary House inquiry. I knew that the Centenary House inquiry was not even under way. But really, this matter relates to the question I asked Senator Cook back in March, two months ago.

Senator Evans has kept only one promise in regard to the accountability package that he announced virtually to the day three months ago. But Senator Evans misled us on the resourcing of the Auditor-General, he misled us on the Centenary House inquiry and he has misled us on the ministerial code of conduct. So one out of four `ain't bad'. But if he were at school, he would not get a special kookaburra stamp—he would get red ink all over his essay.

The last thing I want to relate is the ongoing effects of the sports rorts affair and the fact that the Senate should still inquire into this matter. It is not gone. TALK.START.PARA: —He is just telling outright lies.
—Would you direct your remarks through the chair, Senator Schacht—and Senator Campbell.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I am looking straight at you and I am directing my remarks through you. PARA.TAB: The $600,000 that went into the seat of Swan could have been spent encouraging thousands of young people in that seat to be involved in sport and of those thousands of young people—and many of them could have been disabled sportspeople or Aboriginal sportspeople—there could have been budding young athletes. There might already be masses of private and voluntary and community sporting facilities which now have to compete against the very facilities that this Labor government's corrupt pork barrel, sports rorts scheme has built. The sports rorts affair cannot be allowed to rest in Australian politics. We have had one insignificant, failed, unaccountable minister resign. At the end of the motion, add, "and the Senate also:

SPEECH.PARA: (a)condemns the government for its entirely unsatisfactory response to the Auditor General's reports on Sports Rorts on which $60 million was spent in a blatant program of political pork barrelling, and

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want firstly to comment on this amendment. I thank Senator Campbell for removing those words. The crux of the issue is the fact that some electorates did indeed get facilities that enabled them to increase participation in sport, recreation and cultural facilities, but other electorates did not. As we have been through this issue time and time again, I will not go into it now. The reasons some electorates did not receive funding were spurious, based on a direct relationship between who the actual members were and which parties they belonged to.

PARA.TAB: This brings me to some comments made by the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories about the new direction that the Australian Labor Party is taking with regard to funding for sport. I certainly support what the minister is saying about participation, about encouraging young people to be involved, and about putting money into it. That is all fine. It all sounds wonderful. But when one actually looks at what it means on the ground, one begins to wonder.

Firstly, these groups still need facilities. Yes, fine, there are already some there, but we cannot simply presume that the community is going to pick up where the government left off. I speak particularly of those communities which have been applying year after year—communities which even have full council approval and totally committed community organisers putting in very detailed applications for sports grants, only to find that they were continually rejected. We see now that they were rejected simply because of the seat to which that particular facility was tied. So I ask the minister to think again about whether we really need some sort of facilities program. The Australian Democrats argue that we do.

If the government is really serious about the participation of young people in sport it will start where it really should begin, and that is in schools. We should have a Commonwealth program to ensure that we have properly qualified and dedicated physical education teachers at primary school level across this country. As well, physical education should be a recognised subject in its own right in all secondary schools. That is simply not happening, partly because of restrictions that now exist with so many things being crowded into the school timetable and partly because physical education needs more resources than many other subjects. It is supposed to have fewer students which again, when schools are under enormous financial stress, means that it is one of the subjects put towards the bottom of the list.

We have schools which are desperately short of recreational facilities that senior secondary students in particular should be using when they move into programs in later high school years. This is not so much for competitive sports such as football and netball but for sports that give students a chance to participate in recreational activities such as squash, golf or tennis when they move on from school. If the minister is really serious about participation for young people he will start where this should be starting, and that is in our primary and secondary schools.

I move on to the Auditor-General's report No. 9 and the government response. The reason why the Australian Democrats are supporting Senator Campbell's motion is that certainly there has been retribution. We were led to believe that the Auditor-General would see an increase in money, staff and resources but, when looking at what has now happened, I see no way for the Democrats other than to support this motion of Senator Campbell.

I look forward to hearing how the minister's new-found interest in participation will actually be translated on the ground into more young people having access not just to competitive sports, but to a whole range of genuine physical activities that give them an understanding of what it is to be fit, to experience what it is like to be physically fit and to have those levels of fitness maintained throughout their schooling careers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak to the government's response to Auditor-General's report No. 9, and to support the motion moved by my colleague Senator Campbell.

PARA.TAB: It is interesting to note in the government's response that the Department of Finance sought information from a whole lot of portfolios as to the programs which might be considered to be similar to the community cultural, recreation and sporting facilities program. It came out with a number of categories one of which attracted me. It referred to payments under which grants are paid to individuals, organisations or other governments where the payments are permissive or discretionary. That is a very quaint choice of words in view of the Auditor-General's report on the whole sports rorts affair. It goes on to define them, but I think the words `permissive' and `discretionary' were very apt in these circumstances.

The government appended a schedule listing those items which were described as permissive or discretionary. I added them up. I found there were 230, plus or minus a few, that were permissive or discretionary—in other words, 230 programs that would fit the bill of being similar to what happened with the sports grants. I submit that this represents very fertile ground for future investigations by the Auditor-General if this government does not take away his funding—as has already been referred to by my colleague Senator Chapman and by Senator Lees—because certainly the Auditor-General has suffered thus.

Recently I spoke at an educational seminar in this place which was attended by a lot of people from the Auditor-General's office. They were genuinely concerned about the fact that they were being singled out for treatment by this government because of their actions in doing their job. One person actually asked me what they should do in the future. I said, `Be fearless. Continue to be fearless, because you are the guardians of the taxpayers' money—of how government spends its money'. That is the role of the Auditor-General and nothing could enhance that perception of it more than what happened with Auditor-General's report No. 9. I have raised the issues of pork-barrelling of taxpayers' money and sports grants, as have Senator Baume, Senator Campbell and others over a couple of years, but it was not until the Auditor-General's report came down that the media grabbed it and took notice of it. I think that reflects the high credibility of the Auditor-General, and he should maintain it.

I want to address a concern that was expressed in the media and was raised by me and Senator Crane in the estimates hearings and that is the concern that, because the Auditor-General did his job—in fact, because he carried out his statutory duty—he has been singled out for adverse attention by this government. Articles in the Canberra Times had pointed out that senior public servants and statutory officers were to be given a 20 per cent pay increase if they went on to contracts. The indications in the newspaper were that cabinet had looked at this, decided to penalise the Auditor-General and used a trick to do it.

That trick was to say that if a person was 60 years of age or over that person could not participate in a contract. That person would therefore not get the benefit of the wage increase which would then reflect on the officer for the rest of his or her life after retirement. But, guess what, cabinet picked up the head of the Department of Defence, Mr Tony Ayers, as well—an unintended consequence. That is the sort of dirty pool that this government is suspected of playing.

I raised this at Estimates Committee D, asking Senator Cook whether Tony Ayers had been picked up in this process. If that were the case it would be a scandal of momentous proportions. Putting to one side what was done to the Auditor-General, the unintended consequence was Mr Tony Ayers suffering disadvantage simply because he was over 60 and the government was really trying to get hold of Mr John Taylor. Senator Cook said that he would view such a thing seriously too, but he went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: The Auditor-General is subject to the Remuneration Tribunal.
I see that Senator Coates, who was chairman of that committee, is in the chamber, and I recall he made a similar remark. I then asked:
But was the decision to make 60 the cut-off a Remuneration Tribunal decision or a cabinet decision?
The officer in attendance did not know. Then the chairman, Senator Coates, said:

I must say I had assumed that the decision, or the proposal, applied to heads of executive departments and that statutory officers who were already appointed for fixed terms were not relevant to this matter.

Senator Cook went on to say that this was something for the Public Service Commissioner rather than for the Department of Finance. I raised the fact that the Auditor-General was responsible to the Minister for Finance and then asked:
Can I get some answer as to where it sits and who is going to make the final decision?

I wanted to know if the Auditor-General was going to be chopped off. The allegations in various newspapers were that because he had done the job he was being singled out for treatment. Senator Cook responded that this matter was not an appropriate one to raise at this point. He said:
We do not want to set a precedent for doing it in a cacky-handed sort of way just because we happen to be before you.

That is the sort of language we have to come to expect from the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). I have not heard it much from Senator Cook and I was somewhat surprised by it. It seems to me that an answer should have been given. I do not believe that the chairman was in a position to know one way or another, but he offered an opinion.

PARA.TAB: It was made pretty clear to me that this was all to do with the Public Service Commissioner. By way of comparison, at the estimates committee hearing into industrial relations, Senator Crane questioned Senator Ray about this same matter. Senator Crane asked whether Mr Tony Ayers from the Department of Defence had got caught up in the contract arrangements that were being put in place which would increase salary by trading off tenure. Senator Ray responded by saying that Mr Brereton was writing to the Remuneration Tribunal to put an alternative, and that he understood that it rested with the Remuneration Tribunal. Bear in mind that I had a different answer from Senator Cook.
Senator Crane went on to talk about other things and the possibility that Mr Ayers had got caught up in this. Senator Crane asked Senator Ray:

SPEECH.PARA: Does this affect senior officers in any other department?
He was referring to the cut-off at 60. Senator Ray said:
It does not affect any departmental secretaries. As I understand—I will get confirmation in a moment—the Remuneration Tribunal has to consider cases of statutory officers.
Senator Coates had said that statutory officers had already been appointed for fixed terms and were not relevant to this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —A reasonable opinion.
—Okay, it was his opinion at the time. Senator Ray said that the Remuneration Tribunal had to consider cases of statutory officers. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: I think cabinet originally asked—
another tricky manoeuvre—
for six statutory officers to be considered in this round. The Remuneration Tribunal said, `No, that list is not comprehensive.'
It must have been a wake-up to all this. He continued:
I think it is now looking at about 60 statutory officers and is due to report back on those in a package.
Senator Crane then asked:
Does this also `catch' the Auditor-General, Mr Taylor.
Senator Ray said:

The Auditor-General is a statutory officer beyond the age of 60. Therefore, what alternatives exist for him may well be caught up in the review of all statutory officers. If he is the only one affected, he may well also have the option that I hope Mr Ayers has.

Obviously, Senator Ray was embarrassed. Here we had a senior departmental official—one of the most senior in the country—being penalised as an unintended consequence of what appears to be the government saying to the Auditor-General, `Because you did your statutory job, because you brought out report No. 9, because in the process the whole sports rorts affair was uncovered, we are going to penalise you.' If that is the case—I do not know that it is—it is one of the most disgraceful acts to be perpetrated by any government since Federation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I only wish to speak on one aspect of this particular report, which has been well and truly covered by my colleagues in a very capable manner. As a result of the sports rorts affair and the Auditor-General's findings, we have a situation where the government has done a complete about-face and has run for its life. We have to say, `What happens now?'

PARA.TAB: Senator Faulkner came into this chamber and said, `We are now concentrating on the human aspects of sport, on attainment of personal goals by athletes rather than bricks and mortar.' That is fine, but I want to know what is going to happen with some of our athletes in Tasmania.

There have been a lot of discussions and promises of cooperation between local government bodies in southern Tasmania, in the metropolitan area and the state government. If the federal government is fair dinkum about providing support for our athletes up until the Olympic Games, I would have thought that at least it would have given strong consideration to the proposal being mooted by the state government and the Hobart City Council towards building a new aquatic centre in Hobart to serve the whole of Tasmania, and particularly the metropolitan area.

The Hobart City Council has promised $4 million to the project, and the state government has also promised $4 million to the project provided that some funds are made available by the federal government. TALK.START.PARA: —You also know what the limits were on grants.

—I notice Senator Coates is interjecting. I wonder how much lobbying he has done on behalf of his constituents in Tasmania. All the Labor senators have been very quiet. I would suggest that the Labor senators must feel rather embarrassed that the union movement has taken up the cause. The head of the Trades and Labour Council, Jim Bacon, has put together a deal in an attempt to get some money through the white paper program. I congratulate him for that. There was no mention of this by any of the Tasmanian Labor politicians—particularly the local member, Mr Kerr. As I said, they must be very embarrassed that a lateral thinker like Jim Bacon seems to have gained government support through one of the new Working Nation programs. He may have achieved the success that the Labor members failed to achieve. I wonder how hard they lobbied.

PARA.TAB: Now that Mr Bacon and the TLC have announced their plans we notice that people from all over the place are jumping on the bandwagon. According to a press release of 25 May, the local member for Denison has expressed support. Obviously now that someone else has come up with an idea everybody is jumping on the bandwagon.

When Senator Faulkner was asked about this particular matter he, along with the Prime Minister, said that no funding would be available for this project and the money was going to be spent on helping athletes. I want to know how our athletes in Tasmania are going to be able to train with outdated and outmoded facilities. I hope that the Labor Party members and senators from Tasmania will support this proposal as strongly as they can and gain the needed $2 million from the federal government to allow the aquatic centre to proceed. TALK.START.PARA: —I will not detain the Senate for very long because I have not heard all the debate and I cannot respond to all the things that have been said. I want to briefly respond to some of the comments made by Senator Parer. The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Chapman)—In accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present the following report of the Auditor-General:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Efficiency audit—Department of Employment, Education and Training—implementation of a new program—landcare and environment action program.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I am responding to the Auditor-General's report on the landcare and environment action program. The Auditor-General has selected this particular program for study because of DEET's large involvement in the area of providing employment, and this is a new program. One of the reasons why I suspect that the Auditor-General has chosen this program is DEET's poor record over the years in implementing job related programs.

PARA.TAB: However, in this case, looking at what the department has done with the LEAP, it seems like the department has got off to a reasonable start. If one was actually scoring the department, one would give it a six out of 10. There are a number of things in the planning, implementation, monitoring and reporting of this program that the Auditor-General has shown some concerns about and indicated a very definite need for DEET to tighten up its performance in this area; but, overall, it is not too bad.

In many ways it is an important initiative. It is a response to the concerns about youth unemployment which came to a head the year before last when we had the youth summit here in Canberra which I attended. On that day enormous concern across the countryside from all sorts of levels of organisations was expressed from people such as the head of the national chamber of commerce right down to the people who were victims of this government's savage recession in which we were at the depths of at that point.

The government has come up with a number of initiatives to help solve the problem of youth unemployment and this is one of the more imaginative ones. Not only is it targeting an area of high unemployment, that is youth unemployment, but by its very nature it is also providing a very necessary service to the country in that a lot of the work is focused on the restoration of the land, not only in rural areas but also in urban areas. It helps to restore the environment and the heritage of this country and, therefore, the direction in which this government is heading with this project is to be applauded.

However, there are a number of concerns, particularly in relation to the achievements that come out of this initiative not only in the overall level of placement for people who need work experience but also the types of groups that are receiving that experience and the regions that are gaining the places. In that light, in a minute, I will draw to the attention of the Senate one case study where I believe that the implementation of the LEAP has left a lot to be desired. I know my colleague Senator Brownhill in his area has also come across problems with the implementation of this scheme, and he will be talking about another case study. But let us look first of all at the achievements of this scheme.

Under the LEAP there have been 5,500 commencements out of 9,000 contracted places and $55 million has been spent on this project—curiously, as the Auditor-General reports, 99 per cent of the funding. If, originally, 9,000 places were to be provided and only 5,500 have been provided which, according to the figures, takes up 99 per cent of the funding, one wonders what would have happened if the department had actually contracted out the full 9,000 places. Where would the money have come from for that? It seems that the department was a fair way under target because, obviously, the money was not there to place more. There was a real opportunity to place more people because some of the figures I will read out a little later indicate that the people who set up brokerages to operate this program were certainly around and that great numbers of them were rejected.

One of the positive things about the small number of placements that were made related to the composition of the people who were employed. Six per cent of places went to the disabled and eight per cent went to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders. Even though 27 per cent went to the long-term unemployed, I would suggest to the Senate that that figure is far too low given that the chances of the long-term unemployed getting any new jobs that come up is about 10 in 100—they only have a 10 per cent chance of picking up new employment. One would have thought that an initiative like this perhaps would have balanced out a little better and given them a higher ranking.

The specific case study which shows the inadequacies of the way in which this program has been administered relates to my own area of Newcastle where the Newcastle Earth Team was a successful broker last year and did place people in positions. The NET set up its infrastructure and was running very well but then the government pulled the rug out from under it. The NET had to recompete with a whole group of new applicants. When the dust settled in that process, the Newcastle Earth Team missed out. What a pity that was because, looking at what it achieved in that year, the government has just wasted an excellent program.

The LEAP, as applied by the Newcastle Earth Team, was designed to assist the 15- to 20-year-olds. Landcare was the vehicle used to provide the experience for working practices, group skills, reliability and punctuality. The program had a duration of 26 weeks. It was comprised of three days per week of hands-on experience and one day per week of classroom activities. The 15- to 17-year-olds were given an allowance of $125 per week, and the ones over 18, $150 per week.

The Newcastle Earth Team had been formed by four non-profit sponsor organisations in Newcastle: Throsby Land Care which has done great work in restoring the mouth of the Throsby basin as it enters Newcastle harbour; Trees in Newcastle which has done quite a lot for the greening of the city; the Carrington Parks Project which is in one of the poorest and more run-down areas of the city and which has done great work in bringing those areas back to life; and Integral Urban Housing. These were all facilitated by the LEAP which the government has now terminated, and places have been taken from an area of great need in the Hunter Valley.

Not only was this program creating great work experience for these people but it was fulfilling a real need in the regeneration of Newcastle's urban environment. Some of the sponsors behind this were some of the top organisations in the city, including the Newcastle City Council. So it was very hard to understand the reasoning behind the government's exclusion of the NET group to run the LEAP. It was a waste of valuable resources in the personnel that set it up and it has deprived people of the opportunity to continue developing their skills.

One of the terrible things about the way this program has been terminated is the fact that people are mid-course. The government has said, `Well, it can be contracted out to other people.' But, if it was a successful program, why not let it continue? It basically comes down to the fact that the government has set up a scheme that operates on short-term budgetary targets. Every year the government reconsiders everything instead of giving people the stability to continue and complete projects over a period. I find it amazing that the government has not done its planning on this basis.

The government seems, quite by accident or by stealth, to have got into a pattern with its budgets of four-year budgeting. Honourable senators will have noticed some of the rather strange outcomes of this. The government will put up a wine tax or a petrol tax. The government will announce it one year, it will go up that year and then it will go up the next year. But the government does not tell us about it the next year; it only tells us about it in the first year, and so all these things sneak up.

If the government was into this long-term budgeting, why should it not do it for this sort of program where it makes a lot of sense? The government should set up a thing and say, `We believe that will work. We will fund it and it will be monitored', and let it go ahead. That would give people security in setting the program. It would allow the program to bed down, the personnel to gain the skill and the students involved in the program to finish off the work; but, no, it gets terminated midstream.

We have come across this sort of thing before. In the area of adult and community education we have had major hearings around Australia and we have found out all about these great programs that were going on but were terminated after one year. I plead with the government to reconsider this procedure and to move into longer term planning than it is doing, and to allow successful programs to bloom instead of chopping them off at the roots as is happening at the moment. These programs are so much needed in our area. In my area there is 49 per cent youth unemployment in the centre of Newcastle and on the north coast nearby unemployment is about 20 per cent, but the government will not fund initiatives that have the potential of the project developed by NET.

When I wrote to the minister about this and asked, `Why are you not continuing to fund this successful program?', all I got back from his parliamentary secretary was a great list of all the ways in which the money is divided up, with so much to each state, so much to each group, and so much to all the regions in the group. But the net effect is that with very successful programs such as LEAP the government has not put in enough resources. It is to the government's unending shame that it has not funded this effort. Not only is there a need for the work to be done in terms of the renewal of the environment, but there is the huge need for the youth of this country to have the opportunity of more jobs, particularly in areas of high unemployment. DEET really needs to sharpen its act in terms of not only redirecting resources to this particular area but also in the way in which it implements the program.

The Auditor-General's report found a number of shortcomings with these programs, and I have pointed out some of them, including the example of NET in Newcastle. But the Auditor-General also found serious shortcomings in planning right across Australia. The report found that in planning there was too much focus on short-term activities, and that is the basic point I have been making in the last few minutes. Shortcomings were found in management, particularly in design, where at federal level those concerned were not really aware of the initiatives of the states in youth and conservation programs. It found that consultation with the states should have started earlier and that targets tended to be a little overambitious. Reporting was not sufficiently detailed and there was evidence that in many cases reports had not even been read—which I find amazing at this stage of the audit cycle.

With monitoring, the Auditor-General's report found insufficient attention was given to the need for monitoring by the CES of LEAP programs. We have seen major changes in the CES because of its inadequacies in major areas. Again, there seem to have been inadequacies in terms of the LEAP program. Overall, the report is saying that what is being done in LEAP is a good start, but that insufficient resources are being applied to it. Some of the processes certainly need sharpening up. Probably the process that needs sharpening up most of all is the fact that these are programs of a one-year cycle. If we get them onto a longer term cycle, we will find that we will get much more efficient outcomes. Things that are established and work will continue, and the youth of Australia will have the opportunity to get the experience they need for work. Finally, in a program like LEAP, the environment vote in the country and the urban areas will be much improved.
